instructions.title: How to Play
instructions.point1: Create a strong password for different security scenarios.
instructions.point2: Use the character buttons to build your password.
instructions.point3: Your goal is to meet all the security requirements shown in the checklist.
instructions.remember: Remember: A good password is easy for you to remember but difficult for others to guess!

social.name: Social Media Account
social.description: Create a strong password for your new social media account. Remember that this will protect all your photos and personal information.
social.tip: For social media, consider using a phrase that's meaningful to you but not easy to guess, combined with special characters and numbers.

bank.name: Online Banking
bank.description: Your bank requires a new secure password for online transactions. This password will have access to your financial information.
bank.tip: Banking passwords should be especially strong. Avoid using information related to your identity like birthdays, and use a mix of all character types.

email.name: Email Account
email.description: Create a strong password for your email account. Remember that your email can be used to reset passwords for other services.
email.tip: Email accounts are often targets for hackers since they can be used to reset other passwords. Consider using a password manager for maximum security.

gameOver.title: Game Complete!
gameOver.message: You've learned how to create strong, secure passwords for different contexts. Keep applying these principles to protect your online accounts!

passwordTips.title: Password Security Tips:
passwordTips.tip1: Use a different password for each important account
passwordTips.tip2: Consider using a password manager to keep track of your passwords
passwordTips.tip3: Change your passwords regularly, especially for sensitive accounts
passwordTips.tip4: Never share your passwords with others or store them in plaintext

linkHunter.findSafeLinks: Click on the links that you think are secure. Look out for misleading URLs, HTTP instead of HTTPS, misspelled domain names, or suspicious domains.

instructions.title: How to Play
instructions.point1: You'll see a list of URLs that might be secure or malicious.
instructions.point2: Your goal is to identify and click only on the safe links.
instructions.point3: Look carefully for signs of phishing, such as misspelled domains or missing https.
instructions.remember: Remember: Always check a URL carefully before clicking on it in real life, especially when it involves sensitive information!

feedback.safeTitle: Good job! This link is safe.
feedback.dangerTitle: Be careful! This is a suspicious link.
feedback.safeMessage: You correctly identified a secure link.
feedback.dangerMessage: This link is potentially malicious or fraudulent.

securityTips.title: Security Tips
securityTips.tip1: Always check for HTTPS (lock icon) in the address bar before entering sensitive information
securityTips.tip2: Be suspicious of URLs with misspelled domain names or unusual extensions

banking.title: Banking Websites
banking.description: Your bank has sent you an email with several links to update your account information. Which ones are legitimate bank websites?

shopping.title: Online Shopping
shopping.description: You're looking for deals on popular retail sites. Identify which shopping website links are genuine and which ones might be scams.

email.title: Email Recovery
email.description: You need to recover your email password. Which of these password reset links would be safe to click on?

links.bank1: This is a secure link. It uses HTTPS and is on the official bank domain (mybank.com).
links.bank2: This link is suspicious. It uses HTTP instead of HTTPS, which means your connection would not be encrypted. Also, the domain 'mybank-secure.com' is not the official bank domain.
links.bank3: This is a fake link. While it uses HTTPS, the domain 'loginportal.net' is not the official bank domain. This is likely a phishing attempt.
links.bank4: This is a legitimate subdomain of the bank's main website, using HTTPS for a secure connection.
links.shop1: This is a scam link. 'amazonshopping.co' is not Amazon's official domain, which is amazon.com.
links.shop2: This is a secure link to the real Amazon website with HTTPS protection.
links.shop3: This is dangerous. It uses HTTP instead of HTTPS and 'best-deals-amazon.com' is not Amazon's official domain.
links.shop4: This is a legitimate link to Samsung's official store with proper HTTPS security.
links.email1: This is a legitimate Google Mail URL with proper security.
links.email2: This is a phishing attempt. 'google-mail-service.com' is not an official Google domain.
links.email3: This is a secure link to Google's official account recovery page.
links.email4: This is a suspicious URL. The domain structure looks like a phishing attempt with multiple subdomains to confuse users.

gameOver.title: Game Complete!
gameOver.message: You've successfully learned how to identify secure and suspicious links online. This skill will help protect your personal information!

linkTips.title: URL Safety Tips:
linkTips.tip1: Always check the domain name carefully - phishing sites often use similar-looking names
linkTips.tip2: Look for HTTPS and a lock icon in your browser's address bar
linkTips.tip3: Be wary of URLs with unusual subdomains or domain extensions
linkTips.tip4: When in doubt, type the website address directly in your browser instead of clicking links

instructions.title: How to Play
instructions.point1: You will be shown emails, websites and pop-ups that could be legitimate or phishing attempts.
instructions.point2: Your task is to identify which ones are safe and which are phishing attacks.
instructions.point3: Look for clues like suspicious URLs, spelling errors, or unusual requests for personal information.
instructions.remember: Remember: Real organizations will never pressure you for immediate action or ask for sensitive information via email or pop-ups.

phishingSigns.1: Suspicious sender address with misspelled domain names
phishingSigns.2: Urgent requests or threats to create pressure
phishingSigns.3: Grammar or spelling errors and unprofessional presentation

safeSigns.1: Correct official domain in email address or website URL
safeSigns.2: No requests for personal information or passwords

email1.title: URGENT: You've WON a Prize!
email1.content:
Dear Customer,

CONGRATULATIONS! You have been randomly selected to receive a FREE iPhone 15 Pro!

To claim your prize, you must ACT FAST and click the link below to enter your personal details within 24 HOURS or your prize will be given to someone else!

We need your full name, address, phone number, and bank details for verification purposes.

Click here: www.claim-your-free-prize.com
email1.explanation: This is a classic phishing email with multiple red flags: urgency to create pressure, too-good-to-be-true prize, suspicious sender address, and requesting sensitive personal and financial information.

email2.title: School Calendar Update
email2.content:
Dear Parents and Guardians,

This is a reminder that the school calendar for the upcoming academic year has been updated on our official website.

You can view the calendar by logging into your parent portal using your existing credentials.

If you have any questions, please contact the school office.

Regards,
School Administration
email2.explanation: This is a legitimate email from an official school domain. It doesn't ask for personal information, doesn't create urgency, and directs you to use your existing login credentials on their official website.

popup1.title: Security Alert
popup1.content:
WARNING: Virus detected on your computer!

Call our technical support immediately at: +1-800-123-4567
Reference code: MS-ALERT#45692

Do not turn off your computer or your data will be lost!
popup1.explanation: This is a fake security alert. Legitimate security software doesn't use alarming pop-ups with phone numbers. This tactic is used to scare people into calling fake support numbers that will request payment or remote access to your computer.

website1.title: Reset Your Facebook Password
website1.content:
Please enter your email and current password to verify your identity:

Email: [                    ]
Current Password: [                    ]

[Reset Password]
website1.explanation: This is a phishing website. Notice the URL is 'faceb00k-login.com' (with zeros instead of 'o's). A legitimate site would never ask for your current password when resetting a password. Facebook's actual domain is facebook.com.

email3.title: Your Microsoft subscription renewal
email3.content:
Hello,

This is a confirmation that your Microsoft 365 subscription has been renewed for another year. No action is required from your side.

If you have any questions about your subscription, please visit our Help Center at https://support.microsoft.com or contact our customer service team.

Thank you for choosing Microsoft.

Microsoft Subscription Team
email3.explanation: This appears to be a legitimate email. It comes from an official Microsoft domain, doesn't ask for any personal information, includes a proper support link to the official Microsoft website, and doesn't create urgency.

gameOver.title: Game Complete!
gameOver.message: You've completed the Phishing Simulator! Remember these skills when browsing the web and checking your emails.

detective.instructions: You're a digital detective! Investigate this news story by clicking on the tools below. After gathering enough clues, decide if the story is real or fake.
detective.decisionPrompt: Based on your investigation, is this news story real or fake?
detective.resultCorrect: Great detective work! You were right!
detective.resultWrong: Not quite right... let's review the evidence.
detective.explanationFake: This was fake news. The story has several red flags: it only appears on social media, the author isn't verifiable, and the date is suspiciously old.
detective.explanationReal: This was real news. The story is reported by credible sources, has a verified author, and includes recent facts that can be checked.

story.title: Famous Celebrity Involved in Shocking Incident!
story.content: A very famous celebrity was reportedly involved in a shocking incident last night! Multiple social media accounts are sharing this breaking news. The incident happened after a private event. Sources close to the celebrity refused to comment.

google.name: Search Online
google.content: You can't find this story on any reputable news sites. It only appears in social media posts and gossip forums.

author.name: Check Author
author.content: The original post was shared by an anonymous account with no history of reporting news.

comments.name: Read Comments
comments.content: Most comments express doubt about the story. Several users point out similar false stories that circulated last month.

date.name: Check Date
date.content: The original post is from three days ago, but claims the incident happened 'last night' on each day it's shared.

factcheck.instructions: Decide if the news is real or fake! Use the buttons below.

news1.title: Scientists Discover Chocolate Cures All Diseases
news1.content: In a groundbreaking study, scientists at a prestigious university have found that eating 100g of chocolate daily can prevent and cure all known diseases including cancer and diabetes.
news1.explanation: This is clearly exaggerated. No single food can cure all diseases. Real medical breakthroughs are reported with specific details about the research and researchers involved.

news2.title: New Research Shows Benefits of Regular Exercise
news2.content: According to a study published in The Journal of Medicine, exercising for 30 minutes at least 3 times a week can reduce the risk of heart disease by up to 40%.
news2.explanation: This is realistic news with specific details - it mentions the publication, gives reasonable statistics, and makes claims that align with established medical knowledge.

news3.title: Child Becomes Superhero After COVID Vaccine
news3.content: A 10-year-old boy has reportedly developed supernatural powers including flight and super strength after receiving a COVID-19 vaccination last month.
news3.explanation: This is clearly fake. Vaccines cannot give people superpowers. Such extraordinary claims would require extraordinary evidence and would be major international news if true.

news4.title: Tech Company Announces New Smartphone Model
news4.content: Tech giant announces their newest smartphone model featuring longer battery life, improved camera, and faster processor. The new device will be available next month starting at $899.
news4.explanation: This is a realistic news item about a product launch with specific details about features and pricing that align with typical smartphone releases.

news5.title: Secret Government Program Controlling Weather Exposed
news5.content: Anonymous sources have revealed that the government has been using secret satellites to control weather patterns and cause natural disasters in enemy countries.
news5.explanation: This has hallmarks of conspiracy theories - anonymous sources, extraordinary claims about government capabilities, and lack of scientific consensus or evidence.

chat.instructions: Respond to cyberbullying messages in the chat. Your choices make a difference!

report.consequence: You reported the offensive message. A notification has been sent to the group administrators.

defend.consequence: You stood up for João. Your support makes a difference in preventing cyberbullying.

ignore.consequence: You ignored the message. While you didn't make things worse, the bullying might continue without intervention.

join.consequence: You joined in with the bullying. This makes the situation worse and encourages others to continue the bullying.

classroom.name: Class Group Chat
classroom.context: You're in a WhatsApp group with your classmates discussing a recent school project. Someone starts making fun of João's presentation.

messages.m1: Has everyone submitted their project presentation slides?
messages.m2: Yes, I sent mine yesterday. The deadline is tomorrow, right?
messages.m3: Did you guys see João's presentation? It was so lame! 😂

feedback.good: Excellent job! You showed how to respond positively to cyberbullying. By reporting or defending, you help create a safer digital environment.
feedback.medium: Good effort! You took some positive actions, but remember that consistently standing up against bullying is important to stop it completely.
feedback.bad: Think about the impact of your actions. By ignoring or participating in cyberbullying, you allow it to continue and cause real harm to others.

post1.author: Alex2005
post1.content: Look at Mark's new profile pic! 😂 I can't believe he thinks he looks good in that shirt. #FashionDisaster #NoFilter
post1.explanation: This is bullying because it publicly mocks someone's appearance and clothing choices, using hashtags to draw more attention to the ridicule.

post2.author: SportsTeam23
post2.content: Great game yesterday! Our team played their hearts out. Looking forward to next week's match!
post2.explanation: This is a positive and supportive post about a sports team. It doesn't target anyone negatively or contain offensive content.

post3.author: CoolKid2023
post3.content: Why is Emma even in our group chat? Nobody likes her anyway. Can someone remove her? 🙄
post3.explanation: This is bullying through exclusion. The post is attempting to isolate someone from a social group and publicly stating that no one likes them.

post4.author: SchoolNews
post4.content: Reminder: Science fair projects are due next Friday. Don't forget to bring your materials tomorrow for in-class work time.
post4.explanation: This is a simple informational announcement with no bullying content. It's providing helpful information to students.

post5.author: GameMaster55

post5.explanation: This is bullying because it publicly shames someone for their academic performance. The hashtags make it even more hurtful by suggesting they should drop out.

post6.author: Anonymous123
post6.content: New group 'Everyone except David' created. Join if you're cool enough 😎 We all know why he's not invited...
post6.explanation: This is cyberbullying through deliberate exclusion and creating an environment where someone is openly left out. It can cause isolation and emotional harm.

post7.author: ArtClub
post7.content: Art exhibition this Friday! Everyone is welcome to display their work. Sign up sheet is in the cafeteria.
post7.explanation: This is a positive announcement inviting everyone to participate in a school activity. It's inclusive and doesn't target anyone negatively.

project.title: The Project
project.description1: "ClickSmart" is an educational game developed to help young people navigate safely and responsibly in the digital world. Through interactive scenarios and meaningful choices, players learn about misinformation, cyberbullying, and data security in an engaging and practical way.
project.description2: The project was created with the mission of promoting digital literacy and forming conscious digital citizens, capable of making ethical and safe choices online.

digitalCitizenship.title: What is Digital Citizenship?
digitalCitizenship.description: Digital citizenship refers to the responsible, ethical, and safe use of digital technologies. This includes skills such as:
skills: Critical thinking to evaluate online information
Ethical behavior and empathy in digital interactions
Protection of privacy and personal security
Understanding of digital rights and responsibilities

cyberbullying.description: Discover how to react and intervene in online harassment situations.

security.description: Practice protecting your personal data and recognize phishing attempts.

detective.description: Investigate news stories and learn how to find clues that reveal if a story is true or fake.

factcheck.title: Fake or Fact

fakenews.description: Learn to identify and combat false information that spreads across the internet. This module will help you develop critical thinking skills to differentiate between reliable news and misinformation.

howItWorks.conclusion: Each decision made affects your score and provides learning about safe and responsible digital practices.

misinformation.title: Misinformation
misinformation.description: You're in a WhatsApp group with colleagues. Someone sends a sensationalist news: "Celebrity X died in an accident!". There's an urgent request to share it.

share.text: You immediately share it with your contacts.
share.feedback: Sharing information without verification can spread misinformation. It's important to confirm the veracity of news before sharing them.

research.text: You research the news in official sources.
research.feedback: Excellent decision! Verifying information in reliable sources is the best way to combat fake news.

ask.text: You ask the person about the origin of the information.
ask.feedback: Questioning the source is a good start, but verifying in official sources is even more effective.

ignore.feedback: Not spreading dubious information is positive, but verifying and alerting others could be even better.

quiz.question: Which of these sites is most reliable for verifying news?
quiz.explanation: Official newspapers with editorial teams have fact-checking processes before publishing news, making them more reliable than anonymous or unverified sources.

cyberbullying.title: Cyberbullying
cyberbullying.description: In a class chat, a classmate starts being insulted because of the clothes they wore. The insults increase, with offensive emojis and memes.

ignore.feedback: Ignoring bullying allows it to continue. As a bystander, you have the power to intervene and make a difference.

defend.text: You defend your classmate and report the behavior.
defend.feedback: Excellent choice! Defending someone who's being bullied and reporting inappropriate behavior is the best way to combat cyberbullying.

joke.text: You make a joke to lighten the situation.
joke.feedback: Trying to lighten the situation might help momentarily, but it doesn't solve the problem. It would be better to report the behavior or directly defend your classmate.

participate.text: You join in with offensive comments.
participate.feedback: Participating in offensive comments only worsens the situation and contributes to cyberbullying, causing more emotional damage to the victim.

quiz.question: Which of the following actions is most effective against cyberbullying?

options.report: Reporting the behavior to a responsible adult or the platform
options.insult: Responding to bullies with insults too

quiz.explanation: Reporting the behavior to responsible adults or platforms is the most effective way to combat cyberbullying, as it allows competent authorities to intervene and take necessary measures.

security.title: Digital Security
security.description: You're on a sweepstakes website that asks for your phone number, and a pop-up appears saying you've won a prize. To receive it, you need to provide your tax ID and email.

fillData.feedback: Providing personal data to unknown sites can lead to identity theft or fraud. It's important to verify the credibility of the site before sharing sensitive information.

research.feedback: Excellent choice! Researching the site before providing any data is an essential security practice to avoid scams and phishing.

close.feedback: Closing the site is a good initial reaction, but researching about it can help you confirm if it's legitimate or fraudulent, and gives you knowledge to alert others.

askFriend.text: You ask a more experienced friend.
askFriend.feedback: Asking for help from someone more experienced is a good idea, but it's important to develop your own verification skills. Combine this approach with research about the site.

quiz.question: What is a common sign that a website might be fraudulent?

options.privacy: The site has a detailed privacy policy
options.https: The site has a security certificate (HTTPS padlock)
options.prizes: The site offers extraordinary prizes or discounts without apparent reason
options.contact: The site has a contact section with physical address

quiz.explanation: Offers too good to be true, such as extraordinary prizes without apparent reason, are often signs of fraudulent sites or phishing attempts. Always be suspicious of offers that seem too good to be true.

instructions.title: How to Play
instructions.point1: You'll be presented with different cybersecurity scenarios where you need to make decisions.
instructions.point2: Each choice has consequences that will be shown through animations.
instructions.point3: You'll learn what happens when you make different security decisions.
instructions.remember: Remember: In real life, poor security choices can lead to real consequences for your data and privacy!

phishing.title: Suspicious Website
phishing.description: You receive an email that appears to be from your bank, asking you to update your account information. The link leads to a website that looks like your bank's site but the URL is 'my-secure-bank.com' instead of the official 'mybank.com'.

choices.fill: Fill in your data as requested
choices.check: Check the URL and security certificate

consequences.fill: Your login credentials were captured by cybercriminals. They accessed your account and transferred money to their account.
consequences.check: You noticed that the URL isn't official and the site doesn't have the secure padlock icon. You avoided a phishing attempt.
consequences.close: You avoided entering any data on the suspicious site. This protected you from the phishing attempt.

lessons.fill: Always verify the URL of websites where you enter sensitive information. Look for https:// and the padlock icon, and check the domain name carefully.
lessons.check: Great job! Checking the URL and security certificate is a crucial step before entering sensitive information online.
lessons.close: Good instinct! When in doubt about a website's legitimacy, it's safer to close it and contact the company directly through official channels.

password.title: Creating a Password
password.description: You're creating a new account for an important service and need to set a password. What type of password would you choose?

choices.simple: A simple, easy-to-remember password like '123456' or 'password'
choices.strong: A complex password with letters, numbers and symbols like 'K7%j9@Lp2$xR'
choices.reuse: Reuse a password you already use for other accounts

consequences.simple: Your simple password was cracked in seconds by an automated program. Your account was compromised.
consequences.strong: Your complex password would take thousands of years to crack with current technology, keeping your account secure.
consequences.reuse: One of your other accounts was breached, and hackers tried the same password on multiple services. They gained access to all accounts with the same password.

lessons.simple: Simple passwords are incredibly vulnerable to brute force attacks. Even adding a few unusual characters makes a password exponentially more secure.
lessons.strong: Strong passwords that mix character types are much more secure. Consider using a password manager to create and store complex passwords.
lessons.reuse: Using unique passwords for each account is essential. If one service is breached, your other accounts remain protected.

publicWifi.title: Public Wi-Fi
publicWifi.description: You're at a coffee shop and need to check your bank account balance. The coffee shop offers free, open Wi-Fi with no password required.

choices.useVPN: Connect using a VPN before accessing your bank account
choices.login: Connect directly to the Wi-Fi and login to your bank
choices.wait: Wait until you get home to use your secure network

consequences.useVPN: Your connection was encrypted through the VPN, protecting your data from potential eavesdroppers on the public network.
consequences.login: Someone on the same network was using packet sniffing software and captured your login credentials when you entered them.
consequences.wait: You avoided connecting to your sensitive accounts on an insecure network, protecting your data.

lessons.useVPN: Using a VPN creates an encrypted tunnel for your data, making public Wi-Fi much safer for sensitive transactions.
lessons.login: Public Wi-Fi networks are often unencrypted, making it possible for others to intercept data you send or receive.
lessons.wait: For highly sensitive actions like banking, using a trusted network is always the safest option.

gameOver.title: Simulation Complete!
gameOver.message: You've learned about the real consequences of different security choices. Keep applying these lessons online!

securityTips.title: Key Security Tips:
securityTips.tip1: Always verify the URL before entering sensitive information
securityTips.tip2: Use strong, unique passwords for each important account
securityTips.tip3: Be cautious when using public Wi-Fi for sensitive activities
securityTips.tip4: Keep your software and devices updated with security patches
